journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Circumferential Labral Tears Resulting From a Single Anterior Glenohumeral Instability Event
title-group.subtitle: A Report of 3 Cases in Young Athletes

article-meta.aff: *Department of Orthopaedics, Walter Reed National Military Medical Center, Washington, District of Columbia
†John A. Feagin, Jr. Sports Medicine Fellowship, Keller Army Hospital, West Point, New York
Investigation performed at Keller Army Hospital, West Point, New York

author-notes.corresp: ‡Brett D. Owens, MD, Associate Professor, John A. Feagin, Jr. Sports Medicine Fellowship, Keller Army Hospital, 900 Washington Rd, West Point, NY 10996 (e-mail: b.owens@us.army.mil).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

body.p: Accurate identification of the pathoanatomy after shoulder instability events guides surgical treatment. Detachment of the capsuloligamentous complex from the glenoid rim (Bankart lesion),5,6,26,27 impression fracture of the posterolateral humeral head (Hill-Sachs lesion),8,14 superior labral anterior and posterior (SLAP) lesions,12 attenuation of the capsular ligaments,19,32,33 disruption of the subscapularis tendon,11,16,28,29 and humeral avulsion of the inferior glenohumeral ligaments (HAGL)3 have all been described after shoulder instability events and contribute to recurrent instability. The pathoanatomy most frequently encountered after a first-time anterior shoulder dislocation in a young athlete has been characterized as a Bankart lesion in 87% to 100% of patients and a Hill-Sachs lesion in 64% to 100% of patients.4,20,30 Recently, the pathoanatomy of first-time anterior subluxation events was also defined, showing a high proportion of Bankart and Hill-Sachs lesions as well.23

Combined lesions, including triple labral lesions involving avulsions of the anterior, posterior, and superior labrum, have been increasingly recognized and reported.18,22,31 In 1 recent series, 6.5% of all patients who underwent labral repair had a triple lesion, and 28.8% had combined lesions—lesions of the glenoid labrum in more than 1 functional area (eg, Bankart-SLAP).22 Circumferential (360°) tears of the glenoid labrum, defined by complete detachment of the labrum from the glenoid, were first described by Powell et al25 as a type IX panlabral lesion. Lo and Burkhart18 retrospectively reviewed 7 patients with triple labral injuries (combined SLAP, Bankart, and reverse Bankart lesions) and 2 of these patients had circumferential labral tears without any area of labral attachment to the glenoid. Both patients were noted to have chronic recurrent instability. In the largest series of circumferential labral tears, Tokish et al31 reported that all 39 patients had a history of chronic recurrent anterior and/or posterior shoulder instability.

We present 3 cases of circumferential labral tears after an isolated, first-time, traumatic anterior shoulder instability event. All 3 cases presented to a single surgeon (B.D.O.) during a 1-year period. We are unaware of other reports of circumferential labral tears occurring after a single instability event.

sec.title: Case 1
sec.p: A 17-year-old right-hand-dominant male athlete sustained a first-time anterior glenohumeral dislocation while falling onto his outstretched hand in an attempted tackle playing football. He underwent closed reduction by a trainer on the playing field, with a concentric reduction of the glenohumeral joint without evidence of fracture on postreduction radiographs. Evaluation in the orthopaedic clinic 1 week from injury demonstrated a positive O’Brien active compression test, 3+ anterior load shift, 1+ posterior load shift, 2+ sulcus, positive anterior apprehension, and a positive relocation test. His contralateral shoulder examination was normal and there were no signs of ligamentous laxity. He was neurologically intact in all nerve distributions. Magnetic resonance imaging of the shoulder demonstrated findings consistent with a posterior labral tear (reverse Bankart lesion), a SLAP tear, and an anterior inferior labral tear (Bankart lesion) (Figure 1).

caption.p: (A) Coronal fat-suppressed T2-weighted magnetic resonance image without contrast demonstrating increased linear signal within the superior labrum suggestive of a superior labral anterior and posterior (SLAP) tear. (B) Axial fat-suppressed T2-weighted image without contrast with increased signal in the anterior inferior and posterior inferior labrum, suggestive of a combined labral tear.

sec.p: Nine days after injury, the patient was taken to the operating room, where an examination under anesthesia revealed a 3+ anterior load shift, 2+ posterior load shift, and a 2+ sulcus. At arthroscopy, the presence of a circumferential labral tear was confirmed and a 360° labral repair was performed using 8 × 2.4-mm Bio-Composite SutureTak anchors (Arthrex, Naples, Florida). Anchors were placed at the following clockface positions: 12:00, 1:00, 3:00, 4:00, 5:00, 7:00, 8:00, and 9:00. The anterosuperior labrum was absent and a cord-like middle glenohumeral ligament was noted (Buford complex). He performed rehabilitation according to a standard arthroscopic Bankart repair protocol, which included a standard sling for 4 weeks, unrestricted strengthening at 3 months, and return to contact sports at 6 months. This patient returned to full activity at 6 months and was asymptomatic at 18 months postoperatively.

sec.title: Case 2
sec.p: A 20-year-old right-hand-dominant male intercollegiate diver sustained a fall onto an outstretched right arm while snowboarding. The patient sustained a subluxation event where he felt the shoulder “go out and go right back in.” This was his first instability event experienced. Radiographs taken in the emergency room were negative for fracture and confirmed reduction. He was seen in the orthopaedic clinic 2 weeks after initial injury, and his physical examination revealed an intact axillary nerve, 4/5 supraspinatus strength, a positive O’Brien active compression test, 3+ anterior load shift, 1+ posterior load shift, 1+ sulcus sign, positive apprehension, and a positive relocation test. His contralateral shoulder examination was normal and there were no signs of ligamentous laxity. A magnetic resonance arthrogram demonstrated a full-thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon with 1.4 cm of retraction, Bankart lesion, posterior labral tear, and findings consistent with a Hill-Sachs lesion of the posterolateral humeral head (Figure 2).

caption.p: Coronal fat-suppressed T2-weighted image with contrast demonstrating a complete supraspinatus tear and evidence of a Bankart lesion and possible type II superior labral anterior and posterior (SLAP) tear.

sec.p: The patient was taken to the operating room 7 weeks after the date of initial injury and the examination under anesthesia revealed a 3+ anterior load shift, 1+ posterior load shift, and a 1+ sulcus. The presence of a circumferential labral tear was confirmed and a 360° labral repair was performed using 8 × 2.4-mm Bio-Composite SutureTak anchors. Anchors were placed in the following locations on the clock face: 12:00, 2:00, 3:00, 4:30, 5:30, 8:00, 9:00, and 10:00. In addition, the patient underwent a double-row repair of the full-thickness supraspinatus tear using a single double-loaded Bio-Composite Corkscrew medially and 2 polyetheretherketone (PEEK) PushLock anchors laterally (Arthrex). This patient underwent a standard rotator cuff repair protocol, consisting of sling for 6 weeks, rotator cuff strengthening at 12 weeks, and return to contact sports at 6 months. This patient returned to full activity (including intercollegiate diving) at 6 months and was asymptomatic at 15 months.

sec.title: Case 3
sec.p: An 18-year-old right-hand-dominant male patient fell onto his outstretched left upper extremity while running, sustaining a first-time anterior glenohumeral shoulder dislocation requiring manual reduction in the emergency department. Postreduction radiographs in the emergency department demonstrated a concentric reduction of the glenohumeral joint without evidence of fracture. Evaluation in the orthopaedic clinic 2 days after injury demonstrated limited motion: forward flexion, 170°; abduction, 90°; external rotation, 45°; and internal rotation, 60°. Significant findings on examination included a positive O’Brien active compression test, 3+ anterior load shift, 1+ posterior load shift, negative sulcus sign, positive apprehension, and a positive relocation test. His contralateral shoulder examination was normal and there were no signs of ligamentous laxity. A noncontrast MRI scan demonstrated a soft tissue Bankart injury with a Hill-Sachs deformity and a SLAP lesion (Figure 3, A and B).

caption.p: (A) Coronal proton density–weighted spectral selection attenuated inversion recovery (PDW-SPAIR) T2–fat-suppressed magnetic resonance image suggestive of a type II superior labral anterior and posterior (SLAP) lesion and possible anterior inferior labral increased signaling. (B) Axial PDW-SPAIR T2–fat-suppressed image demonstrates a Bankart lesion and Hill-Sachs deformity with possible posterior labral tear. (C) Arthroscopic image of the type II SLAP tear. (D) Arthroscopic image of a Bankart lesion. (E) Arthroscopic image of a reverse Bankart lesion. (F) SLAP repair. (G) View from anterosuperior portal after anterior labrum, posterior labrum, and SLAP repairs.

sec.p: The patient was taken to the operating room 2 months after initial injury and the examination under anesthesia revealed a 3+ anterior load shift, 2+ posterior load shift, and no sulcus sign. At arthroscopy, the presence of a circumferential labral tear was confirmed (Figure 3, C, D, and E). The labrum was repaired in the standard fashion using 8 × 2.3-mm biocomposite OSTEORAPTOR suture anchors (Smith & Nephew Endoscopy, Andover, Massachusetts) placed in the following clockface locations: 12:30, 2:30, 4:00, 5:00, 7:00, 8:00, 9:00, and 11:30 (Figure 3, F and G). The patient underwent an arthroscopic Bankart repair rehabilitation protocol. The patient was progressing well with his physical therapy at 5 months, but was lost to follow-up when he was administratively discharged from our institution for psychiatric issues.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Combined lesions of the glenoid labrum, defined as labral lesions in more than 1 quadrant, are increasingly recognized as a unique pathologic entity.18,22,31 Panlabral tears represent a subset of combined labral lesions, in which the labrum is detached from the anterior, posterior, inferior, and superior glenoid rim. Previous reports of circumferential labral tears have been described in patients with chronic recurrent instability.18,22,31 Authors have hypothesized that recurrent instability provides the pathologic mechanism for circumferential labral tears. This case series represents the first known description of circumferential labral lesions in first-time anterior shoulder instability events and suggests that an alternative mechanism for the development of circumferential labral tears may exist.

Previously reported pathologic changes after first-time traumatic anterior shoulder dislocations have included anterior-inferior labral tears, SLAP tears, capsuloligamentous stretching, rotator cuff tears, and Hill-Sachs lesions.7,13,15,30 The Bankart lesion is the most common pathologic change noted, arthroscopically identified in 89% to 97% of patients after a first-time anterior shoulder dislocation.15,30 Combined labral lesions after traumatic first-time dislocations are uncommon. Bankart and associated SLAP tears are the most common type of combined lesion in first-time anterior shoulder dislocations, with an incidence of 10% to 22%.10,30 To our knowledge, no cases of posterior labral tears have been reported in first-time anterior shoulder dislocations.10,13,15,30

Since Powell et al25 first described the classification of circumferential labral lesions as a type IX SLAP, there have been very limited reports of the injury. Lo and Burkart18 retrospectively reviewed 7 cases of recurrent instability and triple labral lesions in which all patients had combined lesions of the anterior, posterior, and superior labrum. Two of these patients had complete circumferential detachment of the labrum. The authors hypothesized that with an anterior dislocation, a positive apprehension test, and limited clinical evidence of posterior instability, the initial labral injury was anterior, progressing posteriorly, according to the circle concept of instability, into a circumferential lesion.

Tokish et al31 prospectively evaluated 41 shoulders in 39 patients with circumferential labral tears. All patients in this series sustained a minimum of 5 shoulder dislocations. Seventy-eight percent of patients had clinical and radiographic evidence of primarily anterior instability, while 22% of patients had primary evidence of posterior instability. The authors suggest that while an anterior labral tear may be the inciting event, posterior labral tears may also be the provocative lesion leading to a circumferential labral tear.

The circle concept of instability has been proposed as a pathologic mechanism to explain shoulder instability, including combined and circumferential labral tears. The circle concept states that instability in 1 direction (ie, anterior) must be accompanied by a corresponding lesion on the opposite side (ie, posterior).9,21,24 Authors have suggested that the circle concept in patients with recurrent instability may provide the pathologic and biomechanical basis for the development circumferential labral tears.18,31

In contrast to the previously reported cases of circumferential labral lesions,18,31 our patients presented after an isolated initial shoulder instability event. A circumferential labral lesion (as well as a supraspinatus tear in 1 patient) represents a surprising amount of pathologic changes to occur with a single dislocation or subluxation event. The subluxation event in this series is probably best classified as a transient luxation event, given the description of the shoulder “going out then going back in” as well as the pathologic changes noted.23 While previous series propose theories of a progressive mechanism for the development of circumferential labral tears, our series suggests that a single acute mechanism may also result in these combined lesions. Instead of recurrent instability events causing circumferential labral tears, as previously described, it is possible that patients in previous series recurrently dislocated or subluxated as a result of a circumferential labral lesion. Further studies that include first-time dislocators and subluxators are necessary to further identify the incidence and associated mechanism of circumferential labral lesions.

Debate continues on the necessity of arthroscopic stabilization for young patients sustaining a first-time shoulder dislocation. Nonoperative treatment of anterior shoulder dislocations in young athletes may result in recurrent instability rates between 25% and 92% in patients younger than 30 years of age.1,2,7,10 Arthroscopic stabilization after an initial anterior shoulder instability event decreases the recurrence to between 11.1% and 15.8%.7,17 Additionally, operatively treated patients demonstrate improved quality of life assessment scores compared to nonoperatively treated patients.17 Consequently, many authors recommend arthroscopic stabilization for young patients with a first-time dislocation,7,10,22,31 and this is the approach taken at our institution. As demonstrated in this case series, an initial anterior shoulder instability event may produce a more extensive injury pattern than previously reported or appreciated, and early surgical stabilization of these injuries is recommended.
